body: For now just the API. Let's discuss it and then I will add the implementation. This PR is closely related with the #320 one, as the binary writer from #320 will use the byte vector as its backend. That's pretty much the only reason for the byte vector's existence at this point. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379)

comment_regular_data.body:
Review status: 0 of 3 files reviewed at latest revision, 6 unresolved discussions.

---

*[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 63 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f0sUhSMV2J9jddT6d:-K_f0sUhSMV2J9jddT6e:bwovjx0) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L63)):*
> ```objc
> 
>   /**
>    * @return a pointer to the internal buffer.
> ```

Perhaps note that the pointer is not dereferencable when size == 0.

---

*[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 70 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f0339j4CAHB1VCHj3:-K_f0339j4CAHB1VCHj4:b-p4zl8z) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L70)):*
> ```objc
>    *   $reserve() and $shrink_to_fit() calls.
>    */
>   const const uint8_t *data();
> ```

:D let's change apidsl.. `const const` heh.. it's really truly const, as const as it gets. apidsl should have an [error](https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/blob/master/gcc/c/c-decl.c#L9836): `const const const is too const for apidsl`.

---

*[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 96 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-brVI-Xv3zWEDPWO:-K_f-brVI-Xv3zWEDPWP:bgc32ps) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L96)):*
> ```objc
>    * `minimum_capacity` before this function call.
>    */
>   bool reserve(size_t minimum_capacity);
> ```

Useful, but who will use it? I think most use cases will either allocate a zero-length vector (null pointer?) or a maximum size (packet size) vector up front.

---

*[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 104 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f1D0bEOgrDgUlYtlG:-K_f1D0bEOgrDgUlYtlH:boki4n6) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L104)):*
> ```objc
>    * @return True on success, false on failure.
>    */
>   bool shrink_to_fit();
> ```

What concrete use case do you have in mind for this?

---

*[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 111 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-4Sh8540-XufQhPq:-K_f-4Sh8540-XufQhPr:b-befrov) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L111)):*
> ```objc
>    * positions. The internal buffer is automatically reallocated if the current
>    * capacity is not enough.
>    * @param pos Position in the vector starting at which the data should be
> ```

Add empty lines between sections:
- Brief description
- Details
- Params
- Returns
- Other stuff (like `@see`)

---

*[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 117 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-KxW02a2TbpQO8Yi:-K_f-KxW02a2TbpQO8Yj:bzax4um) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L117)):*
> ```objc
>    * @return True on success, false on failure.
>    */
>   bool insert(size_t pos, const uint8_t *src, size_t count);
> ```

I'd mostly be using an append, not really insert. Who would actually be using insert? It requires moving data around (O(n)), so it should generally be avoided.

---

---

*[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 33 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f1WQSin4TpeFdpnZs:-K_f1WQSin4TpeFdpnZt:b-sfps5r) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L33)):*
> ```objc
> %}
> 
> // TODO(iphydf): This should be namespace. Fix apidsl.
> ```

It shouldn't. This is a class as it should be. However, iphydf needs to fix a lot of other things:
- The name `byte_Vector`is ugly.
- We should allow the namespace to be different from the class name (`namespace bv` for `class byte_vector`). I don't have a syntax for it yet.

---


*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

Review status: 0 of 3 files reviewed at latest revision, 7 unresolved discussions. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 33 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f1WQSin4TpeFdpnZs:-K_fMsIWP4vEZ1ZlwScC:b-prlacx) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L33)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
It shouldn't. This is a class as it should be. However, iphydf needs to fix a lot of other things: - The name `byte_Vector`is ugly. - We should allow the namespace to be different from the class name (`namespace bv` for `class byte_vector`). I don't have a syntax for it yet.
Ok, makes sense, now i know what "namespace" actually means -- it's a function prefix. I just copied this TODO line from https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/pull/320/files#diff-0100ed4d7805cfbb62f0132a7cbfda39R11 btw. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 70 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f0339j4CAHB1VCHj3:-K_fNRpgU570-V7TeJBg:bsup91u) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L70)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
:D let's change apidsl.. `const const` heh.. it's really truly const, as const as it gets. apidsl should have an [error](https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/blob/master/gcc/c/c-decl.c#L9836): `const const const is too const for apidsl`.
APIDSL treats the `const` as the class function qualifier rather than the return type qualifier. I'd like it to be ```C++ const uint8_t *data() const; ``` but that didn't seem to work. I figured if I put two consts, one would be class function qualifier and another the return type qualifier, thus `const const`. Now, using `const const const` indeed doesn't make much sense so the error `const const const is too const for apidsl` is appropriate :P --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 96 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-brVI-Xv3zWEDPWO:-K_fO_UXnImF3qyGjKZt:bb1u5lw) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L96)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
Useful, but who will use it? I think most use cases will either allocate a zero-length vector (null pointer?) or a maximum size (packet size) vector up front.
The vector would have this function internally anyway, e.g. when inserting into the vector data that doesn't fit into it, the vector would need to be resized (so it would call `reserve(new_size)`), so it doesn't really cost that much to expose it in the public API and provide some behaviour guarantees. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 104 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f1D0bEOgrDgUlYtlG:-K_fP0oXNVU84M4eeZr4:bo5b0ed) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L104)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
What concrete use case do you have in mind for this?
Just got inspired by `std::vector`, it provides similar functionality. It resized the internal buffer to fit the data it contains, so that there would no unused and wasted memory. byte vector is a general purpose vector, so why not? --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 117 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-KxW02a2TbpQO8Yi:-K_fPfhXBNPVREKyMpBz:bjdc9sx) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L117)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
I'd mostly be using an append, not really insert. Who would actually be using insert? It requires moving data around (O(n)), so it should generally be avoided.
Byte vector is an abstraction over random access array, meaning that you should be able to write things in the beginning, middle and end -- everywhere. Obviously adding data to the end would be less costly than adding it to the beginning, since you don't have to move everything over. If you want to only be able to append data, we should make a byte stack, not a byte vector. We can add convenience functions to vector's interface like `push_back()`, `push_front()`, which would just call `insert()` internally if you like that. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379)*

Review status: 0 of 3 files reviewed at latest revision, 6 unresolved discussions. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 70 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f0339j4CAHB1VCHj3:-K_fV5uhHL_O5-cX5LCe:b-4p5ubh) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L70)):*
Previously, nurupo wrote…
APIDSL treats the `const` as the class function qualifier rather than the return type qualifier. I'd like it to be ```C++ const uint8_t *data() const; ``` but that didn't seem to work. I figured if I put two consts, one would be class function qualifier and another the return type qualifier, thus `const const`. Now, using `const const const` indeed doesn't make much sense so the error `const const const is too const for apidsl` is appropriate :P
Yes, we should change apidsl to have the post-fix const. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 96 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-brVI-Xv3zWEDPWO:-K_fV9glSyaQb3efm8Zi:b2nhll9) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L96)):*
Previously, nurupo wrote…
The vector would have this function internally anyway, e.g. when inserting into the vector data that doesn't fit into it, the vector would need to be resized (so it would call `reserve(new_size)`), so it doesn't really cost that much to expose it in the public API and provide some behaviour guarantees.
Ok. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 104 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f1D0bEOgrDgUlYtlG:-K_fVCsVImsKnUM3tT1D:b7cnhj7) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L104)):*
Previously, nurupo wrote…
Just got inspired by `std::vector`, it provides similar functionality. It resized the internal buffer to fit the data it contains, so that there would no unused and wasted memory. byte vector is a general purpose vector, so why not?
Let's not have this until we actually need it. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 117 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-KxW02a2TbpQO8Yi:-K_fVKGzLen-A2lMdTye:b-ljuk85) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L117)):*
Previously, nurupo wrote…
Byte vector is an abstraction over random access array, meaning that you should be able to write things in the beginning, middle and end -- everywhere. Obviously adding data to the end would be less costly than adding it to the beginning, since you don't have to move everything over. If you want to only be able to append data, we should make a byte stack, not a byte vector. We can add convenience functions to vector's interface like `push_back()`, `push_front()`, which would just call `insert()` internally if you like that.
A stack in its simplest form has push and pop. Accessing other elements requires an additional stack to push popped elements and then push them back (in practice, the libarry probably allows a more efficient method). What we want here is a write-once data structure. We write to it, and then eventually we read the result and send it or store it somewhere. Can we have a simpler interface until we need the complex one? --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379)*

Review status: 0 of 3 files reviewed at latest revision, 5 unresolved discussions. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 117 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-KxW02a2TbpQO8Yi:-K_fWXXmJ2aHLIl6VuRA:b-op7sv0) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L117)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
A stack in its simplest form has push and pop. Accessing other elements requires an additional stack to push popped elements and then push them back (in practice, the libarry probably allows a more efficient method). What we want here is a write-once data structure. We write to it, and then eventually we read the result and send it or store it somewhere. Can we have a simpler interface until we need the complex one?
Sure, I will revise it to be a stack with `push()` for writing, `pop()` for removing and `peek()` for reading, just like we currently have `insert()`, `remove()` and `at()`. Do we want to remove `peek()` and let `pop()` do both removal and reading? --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379)*

Review status: 0 of 3 files reviewed at latest revision, 5 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[toxcore/byte_vector.api.h, line 117 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379#-K_f-KxW02a2TbpQO8Yi:-K_yovAS9TPC5cyE4puM:b7ltkvc) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a5b6448b177ae64250c5832f209587b7548a37ee/toxcore/byte_vector.api.h#L117)):*
Previously, nurupo wrote…
Sure, I will revise it to be a stack with `push()` for writing, `pop()` for removing and `peek()` for reading, just like we currently have `insert()`, `remove()` and `at()`. Do we want to remove `peek()` and let `pop()` do both removal and reading?
Let's just have a very simple growable array abstraction. Give it a function to add one byte and another function to add N bytes. It should be write-once. If we need more, we'll find out later and add the functionality. If we never need it, we can use that fact to optimise the data structure in the future. Fewer constraints = more freedom for the implementation. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379)*

Reviewed 3 of 3 files at r1.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 5 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed.

---



*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/379)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

Coming back to working on this. Forgot a lot of stuff that we have discussed, so re-reading it. I see you suggested making a stack interface, but I don't think that's going to work. The main reason for this is that when we write something into this array/stack, say a network packet or toxsave file, we would want to read the data we have written from the beginning since that's the only way that we can read our binary formats, but stacks read (pop) only from the end, and we can't read out binary formats backwards.
Disregard my last comment, there is no issue with a pop() function as it's not even going to be used for reading.

Can you remind me what is the usage scope of Byte Vector? Will it only be used as a backed for Byte Writer and Byte Reader serialization objects, or would it also be used in toxcore directly (do we even need a general-purpose resizable array anywhere in toxcore?)?

Let's keep this branch around, but I have no immediate plans to use a byte vector for anything. I have some rough thoughts around using msgpack, and then we don't need this. I'm closing it because I can't rebase it so I can't maintain its freshness.

commit.message: Add resizable contiguous memory byte array API

labels.description: Refactoring production code, eg. renaming a variable, not affecting semantics
labels.name: refactor

title: Add resizable contiguous memory byte array
